greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest exponent r such that n^r contains at least one zero digit (in base 10).
comment: Does r always exist? Is it bounded? Is 10 an upper bound?

If n has d digits, the numbers n, n^2, ..., n^k have a total of about N = k*(k+1)*d/2, and if these were chosen randomly the probability of having no zeros would be (9/10)^N. The expected number of d-digit numbers n with f(n)>k would be 9*10^(d-1)*(9/10)^N. If k >= 7, (9/10)^(k*(k+1)/2)*10 < 1 so we would expect heuristically that there should be only finitely many n with f(n) > 7. - _Robert Israel_, Jan 15 2015
The similar definition using "...exactly one digit 0..." would be ill-defined for all multiples of 100 and others (1001, ...). - _M. F. Hasler_, Jun 25 2018
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
maple: for j from 1 do if has(convert(n^j,base,10),0) then return j fi od:
program: [a(n) for n in range(2, 100)] # Tim Peters, May 19 2005
(PARI) A071531(n)=for(k=1, oo, vecmin(digits(n^k))||return(k)) \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Jun 23 2018
xref: Cf. A305941 for the actual powers n^k.
results.author: Paul Stoeber (paul.stoeber(AT)stud.tu-ilmenau.de), Jun 02 2002
